snippet: As the army prepared an assault on Falluja, many residents said they had more sympathy for the Qaeda-backed militants than for the government.
abstract: Many civilians in Falluja, Iraq, say they are more sympathetic toward Al Qaeda-backed militants than government, as fighting rages and army prepares for another assault to take back city; comments underscore complexity of situation.

byline.original: By YASIR GHAZI and TIM ARANGO
byline.contributor: Yasir Ghazi reported from Baghdad, and Tim Arango from Istanbul. Duraid Adnan contributed reported from Baghdad, and an employee of The New York Times from Anbar Province.

lead_paragraph: As the army prepared an assault on Falluja, many residents said they had more sympathy for the Qaeda-backed militants than for the government.

headline.main: In Iraqi City Under Siege, More Support for Militants Than Officials
headline.print_headline: In Iraqi City, More Support for Militants Than Officials

keywords.value: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
keywords.name: organizations
